item.description:
Please join us for the final installment in our 2010|2011 "Bad News/Good News Movie Night Series," in which we will, in turn, immerse ourselves in some of the challenges of our time and then explore the solutions at hand. The first three films (2010) could be considered the dark side and the next set of films after the new year will no doubt inspire, educate and motivate. These films will be held the first Tuesday of each month on the campus of, and co-sponsored by, the University of New England.

NEW!! We have changed the film choice for April in order to premier "Now We're Cookin'" which is a locally produced documentary about how several Mainers and their families are living now in our very own state.  

More info from the makers:

“With the economic crisis and the movement in our country towards sustainable, interedependent living, this DVD provides a fresh look of life off-the-grid,” says Nick Callanan of No Umbrella Media, “It gives insight to the way that all of us could live with a closeness and respect for the natural world.”  

Viewers learn about cooking on the woodstove at Hogback Mountain Farm in Montville.  They find out how to go rabbit hunting with Paul Flynn, owner of Freedom General Store.  They visit with Elsie Gawler the Yentes brothers of North Branch Farm in Monroe and see how these young farmers are progressing without the help of foreign fossil fuels.  Visitors can go runner sledding with the New England Runner Sled Association of Montville and are entertained by the humorous work of the mason John Billings, also of Montville.

Filming for “Now We’re Cookin’” took place entirely on location in the Waldo County towns of Montville, Monroe, Freedom, Palermo and the Kennebec County towns of China.

Here's a trailer:  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7iQTLfyhsD8

This will be a potluck (bring an appetizer/snack or beverage to share for a grazing-style meal) and your potluck kit (plate/utensils/cup/napkin). 6:30 potluck and 7:00 announcements and film. Discussion to follow.

item.why: It's a wonderful new film produced locally about people practicing and promoting independent and self-sustaining lifestyles in Maine.
